p:
Under the elevated [CO 2] condition and air temperature increase at Δ T
a = 1°C (S2), while increasing air temperature shortened the life cycle of both Anopheles and Plasmodium, the decrease of soil moisture and associated habitat index reduced vector abundance, thus alleviating the increase of malaria as a result of global warming. Consequently, in the S2 scenario, we generally find a small increasing trend of malaria incidence (≈ 2−3%) in comparison with present climate conditions (Δ E ≈ 2%, Δ I ≈ 3%, See Fig 9c and 9d).
